channel.title: The Sydney Morning Herald National Headlines
channel.description: The top National headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit http://www.smh.com.au.

item.title: Alex is back, but still trapped in limbo
item.description: As the so-called Pacific solution is dusted off, this asylum seeker remains uncertain of his future - as do many others wanting a new life in Australia, writes Lindsay Murdoch in Bangkok.

item.title: New drugs offer hope to hepatitis C sufferers
item.description: NEW anti-viral drugs costing $50,000 a patient, which cure the most intractable strain of hepatitis C, are presenting the government with a fresh challenge to combat the disease that often afflicts injecting drug users.

item.title: Dark clouds and red dirt
item.description: Local issues such as the intervention, poverty and illiteracy will feature strongly among Aboriginal voters in Saturday's Northern Territory election. Oh, and Julia Gillard will be watching Labor's result very closely, writes Russell Skelton.

item.title: Broderick wants ADF to temper its warrior culture
item.description: The Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Elizabeth Broderick, wants the ADF to fundamentally rethink the way it selects its leaders. She wants to temper the warrior culture that traditionally sees the most senior officers in army, navy and airforce come from backgrounds in combat or command. And she wants to open up more ''gateways'' to the top Defence jobs from other areas within the military such as logistics, human services and health, where the 14 per cent of the ADF who are female tend to be clustered.

item.title: Kyoto 2 crucial to carbon permits - report
item.description: BIG greenhouse gas emitters could pay more under the Gillard government's carbon price if Australia refuses to sign up to a second round of the Kyoto Protocol, a leading climate think tank has said.

item.title: Online chat offers new help for suicide prevention
item.description: A NEW service which uses online chat to prevent suicides is providing support to people in distress who are unwilling to use telephone counselling services.

item.title: Push for more women, safeguards against harassment in military
item.description: A LANDMARK review on women serving in the Australian Defence Force has recommended increasing gender targets and punishing leaders who fail to crack down on abuse and sexual harassment.

item.title: New law to control cyber data
item.description: New laws will allow authorities to collect and monitor Australians' internet records, including their web-browsing history, social media activity and emails.

item.title: Fair Work defends inquiry into HSU
item.description: THE lead investigator for Fair Work Australia has defended the three years it took to investigate the embattled Health Services Union.

item.title: Miners bristle at Greens bid to close royalties loophole
item.description: THE Greens are demanding the federal government close the loophole in the mining tax legislation that enables states such as NSW and Queensland to gouge revenue by raising royalties, saying it would be a cleaner solution than withholding other federal funding.

item.title: Protesting against the carbon tax, one sit-down at a time
item.description: ONE of the unexpected benefits of the carbon tax is that it has transformed the profile of the political protester from a youth with an inexplicable hairstyle and a tendency towards vegetarianism, to a mature person who marches in orthopaedic shoes and is more likely to have a hearing aid tucked behind his ear than a daisy.

item.title: Union official in PM row fled Indonesia
item.description: RALPH BLEWITT, the former union official who wants to give evidence about the alleged rorting involving Julia Gillard's former boyfriend, fled Indonesia in 2009 to avoid arrest after allegedly selling Australian expatriates land he did not own.

item.title: Alarm at plight of red-flagged detainees
item.description: THE Commonwealth Ombudsman has called for the Gillard government to urgently find a solution for refugees deemed security threats by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation whose mental and physical health is threatened by indefinite detention.

item.title: Costello hits out at RBA for silence on bribery
item.description: THE former federal treasurer Peter Costello says the Reserve Bank should have told him and police - instead of covering up - of a June 2007 memo detailing evidence of foreign bribery by one of its subsidiaries.

item.title: Hard work ahead before Nauru centre is ready
item.description: BUILDING a functional refugee processing centre on Nauru able to house the thousands of people to be sent there under a reinvigorated ''Pacific solution'' will take at least three months, with hundreds of asylum seekers set to spend this year living in army tents on the tiny Pacific island.

item.title: It's better to give and receive in kidney transplant shuffle
item.description: SUE HARMER lay in a Melbourne hospital bed after having her kidney removed. Down the corridor her sister Di Abrahams was recovering after receiving a transplanted kidney.

item.title: Olympic Dam on hold as boom peaks
item.description: AUSTRALIA'S biggest resources companies have revealed that more than $50 billion worth of expansion projects will not go ahead as planned, in the latest sign that the peak of Australia's resources boom has passed.

item.title: BHP's Olympic failure leaves $50bn hole
item.description: Australia's biggest resources companies have revealed that more than $50 billion worth of expansion projects have been mothballed.

item.title: Father's age linked to gene mutations
item.description: CHILDREN born to older fathers start life with more genetic mutations than the offspring of younger fathers, scientists report.

item.title: Doctors to be paid for e-health work
item.description: Doctors who help set up patients' electronic health records will receive up to $100 for their work under a compromise deal announced by federal Labor.

item.title: Aussie given World Superbike chance
item.description: Queensland teenager Mike Jones will ride in next month's German round of the World Superbike Championship.

item.title: Minichiello beats ban at NRL judiciary
item.description: Anthony Minichiello has been cleared of a grade three striking charge at the NRL judiciary and will be free to make his 250th appearance this weekend.

item.title: Memo warning RBA chiefs of corruption withheld from police
item.description: A secret memo sent to the 'Deputy Governor RBA' five years ago detailing bribery and corruption within a Reserve Bank subsidiary was withheld from the police, parliament and the government.

item.title: Corryn's body 'bled in car after death'
item.description: Blood or fluids leaked from Corryn Rayney's body onto the back seat of her car after she was killed, her husband's murder trial has heard.

item.title: Bombers still confident of NRL bid
item.description: Potential expansions teams will be hoping their bids are next on the ARLC's agenda after it annouced a new billion dollar TV rights deal.

item.title: Seven LNP nominations for Rudd's seat
item.description: Seven people want to run for the LNP against former prime minister Kevin Rudd in Griffith at the next federal election.

item.title: Karmichael Hunt's AFL season over
item.description: As a war of words erupts over Israel Folau, the Gold Coast Suns have toasted the success of Karmichael Hunt after confirming his season was over.

item.title: Docker Crowley in AFL injury scare
item.description: Fremantle are confident Ryan Crowley will be fit to take on North Melbourne on Sunday despite the tagger injuring his ankle at training.

item.title: Rate cut needed for 2013 growth: Westpac
item.description: Westpac chief economist Bill Evans says lower interest rates will be needed for robust growth to continue in 2013.

item.title: SA government now wary of BHP: premier
item.description: South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill says BHP Billiton will now have to work harder to win over the state government on Olympic Dam.

item.title: Heat risky for worker who died: inquest
item.description: A young man who staggered to his death did work for an insulation company that put the onus of work safety on its contract employees, an inquest has heard.

item.title: Shield quits as FFA refs' boss
item.description: Football Federation Australia is searching for a new director of referees after Mark Shield stepped down from the position.

item.title: Varcoe close to Cats' AFL return
item.description: Geelong are considering speedster Travis Varcoe for a long-awaited AFL injury comeback at Simonds Stadium on Sunday.

item.title: Players waiting on salary cap news
item.description: Some of the biggest names in the NRL are set to benefit from the new TV deal, but player managers are waiting to find out how much money is available.

item.title: Wallaby Cooper set for front-line action
item.description: Wallabies five-eighth Quade Cooper is in line for a Test recall this week and if selected he'll be asked to defend in the front-line against New Zealand.

item.title: Ex-partner challenges Gillard statement
item.description: A former partner of Slater & Gordon, who was present when the firm held an internal inquiry into Julia Gillard, stands by his account.

item.title: Broderick has military revolution in mind
item.description: In her own quiet, thorough and forensic way, what Sex Discrimination Commissioner Elizabeth Broderick is proposing is nothing less than a slow revolution inside Australia’s military.

item.title: Tax not to blame for BHP decision: govt
item.description: The federal government and opposition are at odds over what drove BHP to scrap the massive Olympic Dam mine expansion in South Australia.

item.title: Coca-Cola Amatil to re-enter beer market
item.description: Coca-Cola Amatil has lifted its first half profit and established a new joint venture with Casella Wines for re-entry into the Australian beer market.

item.title: Cloke 50-50 to leave Magpies: Malthouse
item.description: Former Collingwood coach Mick Malthouse says he once believed Travis Cloke will stay with the AFL club, but now thinks it is very much up in the air.

item.title: Man who threatened to kill MPs avoids jail
item.description: A man who threatened to shoot Attorney-General Nicola Roxon and a Victorian state MP has been spared jail by a Melbourne court.

item.title: Titans offer Suns olive branch
item.description: Gold Coast Titans boss David May has begun talks with AFL rivals the Suns in order to avoid future cross code clashes in light of the NRL TV deal.

item.title: Dolphin risk could stop super-trawler
item.description: Federal Environment Minister Tony Burke will have to be satisfied the Australia-bound super-trawler is safe for dolphins, sea lions and albatrosses.

item.title: NRL deal unprofitable: Seven West chief
item.description: Seven West Media chief executive Don Voelte says he couldn't make a profit on showing NRL at the price paid by rivals Nine and Fox Sports.

item.title: Australia imposes new sanctions on Iran
item.description: Foreign Minister Bob Carr has announced new sanctions against Iran in an effort to pressure the Islamic Republic into abandoning its nuclear program.

item.title: BHP profit down by more than a third
item.description: BHP Billiton's net profit has slumped by more than a third to $US15.42 billion ($A14.77 billion).

item.title: Women troops eye frontline jobs: Broderick
item.description: Sex discrimination commissioner Elizabeth Broderick says women soldiers should be able to serve "outside the wire".

item.title: Buckley calls for AFL review
item.description: Collingwood coach Nathan Buckley says the AFL Match Review Panel needs to be overhauled after Will Minson escaped a stomping charge.

item.title: Broncos adopt Origin-style mentality
item.description: Brisbane have gone into finals mode early in a bid to find their best form against defending NRL premiers Manly on Friday night.

item.title: Knives out for Aldi: Father's Day gift pulled from shelves
item.description: Aldi supermarket chain has pulled a $10 pocket knife intended as a limited-time special for Father's Day off its shelves.

item.title: Kennedy and Dick eye Eagles AFL return
item.description: West Coast coach John Worsfold expects Josh Kennedy to play a crucial role when the key forward makes his long-awaited AFL return against Collingwood.

item.title: Accused killer's wife denies faded memory
item.description: The wife of Lian Bin "Robert" Xie - accused of killing five Lin family members in 2009 - has denied that her memory of his whereabouts was faulty.

item.title: Pendlebury AFL mishap but OK for Eagles
item.description: Collingwood's Scott Pendlebury is set to play in the AFL match against West Coast despite suffering a heavy knock during training.

item.title: Union wants Telstra to keep jobs in Aust
item.description: The Communication Workers Union is preparing to 'mobilise' mass demonstrations against Telstra if it moves 651 jobs to the Philippines.

item.title: Assange 'naive' but US to blame for leaks, says ex-spy chief
item.description: The former head of Britain's MI5 security service says it's the US government's fault top secret documents and diplomatic cables were obtained by WikiLeaks.

item.title: States hit back at Swan's funding threat
item.description: Two states have fired back at Treasurer Wayne Swan who is threatening to cut their funding if they increase mining royalties.

item.title: Defence to set targets for more women
item.description: Defence will adopt targets to lift the numbers of women in its ranks, after a report found numerous impediments to recruitment and advancement.

item.title: Stuart to play big role with Daley's Blues
item.description: NSW coach Laurie Daley wants former Blues mentor Ricky Stuart to play a major role in his bid to end Queensland's seven-year State of Origin domination.

item.title: RBA rejects new bribery case allegations
item.description: The Reserve Bank has rejected allegations that its top officers misled a parliamentary committee over a bribery scandal at its note-making companies.

item.title: Opposition links AWU, HSU sagas
item.description: The federal opposition has moved to link scandals surrounding the Australian Workers Union and Health Services Union.

item.title: Nassios satisfied with HSU investigation
item.description: Fair Work Australia investigator Terry Nassios says he is satisfied with the time taken to investigate allegations against the Health Services Union.

item.title: Bid to ban cigarettes for anyone born after 2000
item.description: Tasmania's upper house is calling for a ban on cigarette sales to anyone born after the year 2000.

item.title: Libs to 'outsource' federal bureaucracy
item.description: A senior Liberal says the Coalition will outsource large sections of the federal bureaucracy to state governments, shifting thousands of jobs out of Canberra. Shadow finance minister Andrew Robb criticised much of the Australian Public Service, saying it exists to "leave a paper trail, to cover backsides".

item.title: Pluto costs dent Woodside profit
item.description: Woodside Petroleum's first half profit fell slightly to $US812 million due to the cost of starting up its massive Pluto LNG project in WA.

item.title: Asciano overcomes strikes to lift profits
item.description: Ports and rail operator Asciano has lifted full year profit by 19 per cent despite costs associated with strike action during the year.

item.title: Earthworms don't suck for rare rat
item.description: A unique rat has given up the ability to gnaw in favour of sucking up earthworms, researchers have found.

item.title: Boral lifts full year profit by 5.3%
item.description: Boral has increased its annual profit to $176.6 million but has shied away from giving any guidance on earnings for the new financial year.

item.title: Acting on impulse: why the Kiwis keep coming ... and coming and coming
item.description: They're jumping the ditch in record numbers, chasing the money and better opportunities. But New Zealand's economic refugees say Australia is no paradise: the coffee is worse and people still get laid off.

item.title: Loy Yang buy hits AGL profit
item.description: AGL Energy's recent purchase of a major power station has contributed to a 79 per cent fall in its full year net profit.

item.title: CSL full year profit soars
item.description: CSL has unveiled a 4.5% rise in annual profit to $982.6m and says it can boost earnings even further in 2013.

item.title: Suncorp rewards shareholders
item.description: Insurer Suncorp Group will pay its shareholders a bonus dividend after lifting full year profit by 60 per cent to $724 million.

item.title: Seven West's profit soars after takeover
item.description: Seven West Media has seen its full year profit soar by 97% following its takeover by West Australian Newspaper Holdings.

item.title: ADF report calls for sex abuse crackdown
item.description: Australia's sex discrimination commissioner says deterring women from high-ranking positions will hold back Australia's defence forces.

item.title: Up to PM to clear allegations: Bishop
item.description: Deputy Opposition Leader Julie Bishop says the coalition is unlikely to raise the Julia Gillard law-firm issue in parliament.

item.title: Thomson claim 'sadly pathetic': opposition
item.description: The opposition has dismissed independent MP Craig Thomson's claim that an independent review of a Fair Work Australia investigation clears him.

item.title: Pacific Brands slides further into red
item.description: Pacific Brands has seen its losses blow out to $450.7m and says it expects market conditions to remain challenging in fiscal 2013.

item.title: Calls for probe into note-printing scandal
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia is facing allegations it covered up evidence of bribery by its note-printing subsidiaries.

item.title: Tasmania ban mooted
item.description: The circumcision of boys could be banned in Tasmania after a report on the legality of the procedure.

item.title: Clive Palmer appreciates that patience is a virtue - and so do his guests
item.description: The businessman has a vision - of himself swaying in a top hat at the Melbourne Cup.

item.title: Currency boss: 'Don't email me directly'
item.description: 'What are you guys trying to do, put me in jail?' asked a red-in-the-face John Leckenby, the former chief executive of Note Printing Australia, according to a witness in court yesterday.

item.title: Seven, Ten seek to hook Nine for six
item.description: As Channel Nine celebrates its cricket history with a mini-series about Kerry Packer, bitter rival Channel Seven has emerged as a serious threat for cricket's broadcast rights.

item.title: Black belt barrister to fight for justice from the High Court bench
item.description: A SAWMILLER'S son with a black belt in taekwondo was yesterday appointed Australia's 49th High Court judge.

item.title: Swan warns states not to gouge royalties
item.description: THE federal government has moved to protect its mining tax revenue and slender budget surplus by vowing to penalise dollar-for-dollar any state that seeks to gouge that revenue by increasing mining royalties.

item.title: 'Entirely modern man' Abbott scoffs at claims of women issues
item.description: Tony Abbott laughs off the government's attempt to paint him as having a problem taking directions from women.

item.title: Law firm stands behind Gillard - again
item.description: Julia Gillard has received strong backing for her denials of any wrongdoing as a lawyer 17 years ago from the former Slater & Gordon senior partner who investigated her conduct, Peter Gordon.

item.title: Abbott irons out past indiscretions and steers clear of possible backchat
item.description: ANNIVERSARIES can be a cause for delight, or a bone-crushingly depressing reminder of how little has changed since the day you are memorialising.

item.title: Case raises new questions over Gillard's conduct as a lawyer
item.description: A two-decade old controversy that has dogged the PM is bubbling anew.

item.title: Christchurch revamps and opens for business
item.description: IT WAS a city so widely damaged that when planners wondered how to rebuild, they looked to war-ravaged Beirut for inspiration.

item.title: Coalition backdown on school funding
item.description: THE Coalition has backed away from suggestions private schools are hard done by, with opposition education spokesman, Christopher Pyne, denying the current level of funding for independent schools was an injustice.

item.title: Shock tactics stop teen drivers in their tracks
item.description: WHEN the car Peter Jensen was travelling in sped out of control and slammed into a tree, he suffered a brain injury and lost his leg, injuries he describes as a ''life sentence''. The driver responsible, however, was sentenced to two years in prison.

item.title: Thomson, HSU probe was flawed, review finds
item.description: FAIR WORK AUSTRALIA'S investigation into the troubled Health Services Union, including allegations of wrongdoing by its former national secretary, Craig Thomson, was under-resourced and ill-equipped, an independent review has found.

item.title: How the deal was cut: pizzas, coffee, all-night talks
item.description: FUELLED by caffeine and pizza, rugby league officials negotiated through the night with the managing director of Channel Nine, Jeff Browne, and the chief executive of Fox Sports, Patrick Delany, to finalise a $1.025 billion television rights deal that almost didn't happen.

item.title: Law firm says 'no evidence' against PM
item.description: THE law firm Slater & Gordon and one of its founders, Peter Gordon, have issued separate statements stressing there was no evidence Julia Gillard was involved in any legal wrongdoing while a partner at the firm.

item.title: Paperwork slips up in green rush
item.description: THE federal government's $435 million green energy program failed to keep proper paperwork amid a rush to spend money after the global financial crisis, an auditor's report has found.

item.title: Class war: Gillard's shift on schools
item.description: In her maiden speech to Parliament, Julia Gillard, MP, railed against the 'inequality' in our education system.

item.title: Gyngell's golden point: Nine signs $80m league TV deal in extra time
item.description: Rugby league fans will still only be able to see one live NRL game a week on free-to-air TV for the next five years as part of a carve-up of television rights worth more than $1 billion to the game.

item.title: Memo warned Reserve of bribe fears
item.description: A SECRET memo sent to the ''Deputy Governor RBA'' five years ago detailing bribery and corruption within a Reserve Bank subsidiary was withheld from the police, Parliament and the government.

item.title: Abbott fumbles, stumbles and backflips
item.description: Labor Party officials are overjoyed that Tony Abbott performed a backdown on the second anniversary of the last election.

item.title: Migrants from NZ head here in droves
item.description: Australia is facing a flood of economic refugees. But the big numbers aren't from the north, they are from the across the Tasman, where Statistics New Zealand yesterday announced the biggest exodus to Australia on record.

item.title: 651 jobs to go
item.description: Telstra is sacking 651 staff and will close two call centres in New South Wales and partially shut one in Queensland after a 20 per cent decline in calls from customers.
